page.title: 04Dairying on Stratton Farm
page.content: Stratton Farm maintains two dairies. Each acts independently and has one hundred and thirty Friesan milking cows each, most bred on the farm. There are two bulls: a Hereford and an Aberdeen Angus. Thirty calves at any one time are kept down at the farm. The milk yield today from Higher Dairy from one hundred and ten cows in milk was one thousand seven hundred litres. A day's supply is stored in water-cooled vats and collected daily by tanker at 10.00 am. It is sent to Chard Junction for butter or cheese. The cows fresh in milk are kept in at nights from October and the whole herd is kept under shed cover during the coldest period of the winter. They are fed on silage and cow cake concentrates during this time.
